HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 15, 1926.

ENCOURAGING UNREST
Just as the campus organizations had seemed to settle down
permanently to the state of placid routine and complacent selfsatisfaction which has prevailed ever since the sweeping expansions and improvements of 1922 and 1923, a hopeful note has
again been sounded.
This is none other than the proposed reorganization of the
Hullabaloo. Somehow this respected and time-honored institution escaped the wave of reform that launched the Blue Jay,
changed the policy of •the NEWS-LETTER and revivified the
Musical Club and Barnstormers. Consequently, the year book,
although it has maintained a relatively high standard, has been
laboring under the serious difficulties of unqualified popular
election of its two chief officers and their inexperience in a
highly technical line of work after they are elected.
The plan suggested by the editor of this year's Hullabaloo
is an excellent one. It introduces a system of competition and
puts the year book on the same footing with other campus publications. While the election of chief officers is left in the hands
of the class, the chances for the choice of capable and experienced men are greatly increased by the provision that the candidates must have won places on the Hullabaloo strictly on their
merits.
To secure the adoption the sanction of quite a few of the
powers that be in undergraduate affairs. The merits of the
plan preclude any chance of active opposition, but campus
'inertia remains—an obstacle almost as difficult to overcome,
and twice as discouraging.
We sincerely hope that the Hullabaloo editor will be successful in the campaign of stump speeches that he has already
begun.

THE BEAUTIFUL SNOW
The snow, the snow, the beautiful snow, visited the campus,
not to mention the rest of the city, last week. And as a direct
consequence, the slush, the slush, the gushy slush, is with us
today.
All of which is preliminary to some observations on the
state of the campus. Watery ice has encroached upon the ankles
of the unfortunate editor, the staff is confined to its respective
beds with severe colds and other bronchial affections, and half
of the college world coughs and barks with unaccustomed vigor.
Swear words pollute the fair air of Homewood, swear words
and rasping barks of those who do not use Smith Brothers.
All of these unpleasant happenings are entirely due to ice
and ,slush. It would have been a great help if the laboring staff
of the University could have at least made paths for the stulents' feet. But perhaps the laborers were overworked. Then

Si. John's is out in earnest to
make a showing in lacrosse. The
former soldier boys have booked
a ten-game schedule, and they are
already practicing for the spring
season.
During the last twenty-five years
Of the development of lacrosse we
have had coaching for us "Father"
Bill Schmeiser, who began his lacrosse career by playing at this,
University in 1902. In 1904, CoachSchmeiser published a book entitled "Lacrosse," which gave the
rules and fundamentals of the
game. Since that time he has assisted in the publishing of other
rule books. But he has also been
a moving power in organizing college lacrosse. It was chiefly thru
his efforts that the present National Inter-Collegiate Lacrosse
League was formed. He has been
content to serve in the background
but that which he has done has
been invaluable to the game. His
good work was made a little more
widely known upon the recent acceptance of the "Evening Sun"
Medal.

FINAL CHOICE FOR MEDAL
TO COME AFTER
PRELIMINARIES
Elimination For Tocqueville Medal
To Be Next Month With
Finals In Spring

The preliminary contest for the
1926 award. of The • Tocqueville
Medal will be held in February
and the final choice is to come in
April. This medal, which was not
offered last year, will be awarderl
in 1926 to the winner of a contest
in oral discussion. It is one of
five medals given by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, a distinguished French historian and publicist, to students of American
colleges. One medal goes to Harvard, one to Princeton, one to
Johns Hopkins, one to Tulane, and
one to the Pacific Coast, where it
is awarded in a contest participated in jointly by the University
of California and Leland Stanford University. Hopkins is thus
specially honored in being chosen
to receive one of the medals.
Contest Rules
The subject for the 1926 contest will be the topic: Should the
French Government lease to private corporations its monopolies
of matches and tobacco.
In the preliminary contest each
contestant will speak five minutes
on this topic or on some aspect of
it. Four speakers will be chosen
in this preliminary trial and these
will speak at a student assembly,
giving ten-minute original
speeches on the same topic.
The Tocqueville Medal has long
been regarded as a coveted prize
at Hopkins and the student to
whom ii t has been handed on Class
. .2xNN tee, it prou v. Thc
following are the winners since
1915:

have everything to gain. We have

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 15, 1926.

ENCOURAGING UNREST
Just as the campus organizations had seemed to settle down
permanently to the state of placid routine and complacent selfsatisfaction which has prevailed ever since the sweeping expansions and improvements of 1922 and 1923, a hopeful note has
again been sounded.
This is none other than the proposed reorganization of the
Hullabaloo. Somehow this respected and time-honored institution escaped the wave of reform that launched the Blue Jay,
changed the policy of •the NEWS-LETTER and revivified the
Musical Club and Barnstormers. Consequently, the year book,
although it has maintained a relatively high standard, has been
laboring under the serious difficulties of unqualified popular
election of its two chief officers and their inexperience in a
highly technical line of work after they are elected.
The plan suggested by the editor of this year's Hullabaloo
is an excellent one. It introduces a system of competition and
puts the year book on the same footing with other campus publications. While the election of chief officers is left in the hands
of the class, the chances for the choice of capable and experienced men are greatly increased by the provision that the candidates must have won places on the Hullabaloo strictly on their
merits.
To secure the adoption the sanction of quite a few of the
powers that be in undergraduate affairs. The merits of the
plan preclude any chance of active opposition, but campus
'inertia remains—an obstacle almost as difficult to overcome,
and twice as discouraging.
We sincerely hope that the Hullabaloo editor will be successful in the campaign of stump speeches that he has already
begun.

THE BEAUTIFUL SNOW
The snow, the snow, the beautiful snow, visited the campus,
not to mention the rest of the city, last week. And as a direct
consequence, the slush, the slush, the gushy slush, is with us
today.
All of which is preliminary to some observations on the
state of the campus. Watery ice has encroached upon the ankles
of the unfortunate editor, the staff is confined to its respective
beds with severe colds and other bronchial affections, and half
of the college world coughs and barks with unaccustomed vigor.
Swear words pollute the fair air of Homewood, swear words
and rasping barks of those who do not use Smith Brothers.
All of these unpleasant happenings are entirely due to ice
and ,slush. It would have been a great help if the laboring staff
of the University could have at least made paths for the stulents' feet. But perhaps the laborers were overworked. Then

Si. John's is out in earnest to
make a showing in lacrosse. The
former soldier boys have booked
a ten-game schedule, and they are
already practicing for the spring
season.
During the last twenty-five years
Of the development of lacrosse we
have had coaching for us "Father"
Bill Schmeiser, who began his lacrosse career by playing at this,
University in 1902. In 1904, CoachSchmeiser published a book entitled "Lacrosse," which gave the
rules and fundamentals of the
game. Since that time he has assisted in the publishing of other
rule books. But he has also been
a moving power in organizing college lacrosse. It was chiefly thru
his efforts that the present National Inter-Collegiate Lacrosse
League was formed. He has been
content to serve in the background
but that which he has done has
been invaluable to the game. His
good work was made a little more
widely known upon the recent acceptance of the "Evening Sun"
Medal.

Elimination For Tocqueville Medal
To Be Next Month With
Finals In Spring

The preliminary contest for the
1926 award. of The • Tocqueville
Medal will be held in February
and the final choice is to come in
April. This medal, which was not
offered last year, will be awarderl
in 1926 to the winner of a contest
in oral discussion. It is one of
five medals given by the Baron
Pierre de Coubertin, a distinguished French historian and publicist, to students of American
colleges. One medal goes to Harvard, one to Princeton, one to
Johns Hopkins, one to Tulane, and
one to the Pacific Coast, where it
is awarded in a contest participated in jointly by the University
of California and Leland Stanford University. Hopkins is thus
specially honored in being chosen
to receive one of the medals.
Contest Rules
The subject for the 1926 contest will be the topic: Should the
French Government lease to private corporations its monopolies
of matches and tobacco.
In the preliminary contest each
contestant will speak five minutes
on this topic or on some aspect of
it. Four speakers will be chosen
in this preliminary trial and these
will speak at a student assembly,
giving ten-minute original
speeches on the same topic.
The Tocqueville Medal has long
been regarded as a coveted prize
at Hopkins and the student to
whom ii t has been handed on Class
